qas.question: Which two prominent scientists advanced theories that John N. Gray claims would never have survived the scientific method Popper describes?
Which work by John Gray challenges Popper's falsificationism?
According to Gray, what should have falsified Einstein and Darwin's theories when first proposed?
What kind of thesis does Gray advance about scientific progress?

plausible_answers.text: a theory is scientific only in so far as it is falsifiable, and should be given up as soon as it is falsified.

qas.question: What did John Gray say according to Popper?
Whose theories were compatible with all available evidence when they were introduced?

plausible_answers.text: the progress of science comes from acting against reason

qas.question: Where does Popper state this would have "killed the theories of Darwin and Einstein at birth."?
What thesis does Popper seek to establish?

context: According to John N. Gray, Popper held that "<b4_0>a theory is scientific only in so far as it is falsifiable, and should be given up as soon as it is falsified.<b4_0/>" By applying Popper's account of scientific method, Gray's <a1_0><b7_0>Straw Dogs<b7_0/><a1_0/> states that this would have "killed the theories of <a0_0><b5_0>Darwin<b5_0/> and Einstein<a0_0/> at birth." When they were first advanced, Gray claims, each of them was "at odds with some <a2_0>available evidence<a2_0/>; only later did evidence become available that gave them crucial support." Against this, Gray seeks to establish the <a3_0><b8_0>irrationalist<b8_0/><a3_0/> thesis that "<b6_0>the progress of science comes from acting against reason<b6_0/>."
